articles.headline: Sharing Data, but Not Happily
articles.snippet: Many Americans do not think the trade-off of their data for personalized services, giveaways or discounts is a fair deal, a University of Pennsylvania study found.
articles.abstract: Many Americans do not think the trade-off of their data for personalized services, giveaways or discounts is a fair deal, a University of Pennsylvania study found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should consumers be able to control how companies collect and use their personal data?

articles.headline: Dish Network Joins Deal Mania With Bid for T-Mobile
articles.snippet: A deal would provide an answer to what Dish plans to do with its vast wireless spectrum holdings.
articles.abstract: A deal would provide an answer to what Dish plans to do with its vast wireless spectrum holdings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merger mania has taken over the media business.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and David Gelles

articles.headline: ‘Viagra for Women’ Is Backed by an F.D.A. Panel
articles.snippet: The vote on flibanserin by an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration follows two rejections and a campaign for the drug’s approval.
articles.abstract: The vote on flibanserin by an advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration follows two rejections and a campaign for the drug’s approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: After an intense lobbying campaign, a federal advisory panel recommended approval of what would become the first drug to treat a lack of sexual desire in women.

articles.headline: In ISIS, the Taliban Face an Insurgent Threat of Their Own
articles.snippet: Though their numbers in Afghanistan remain low, Islamic State fighters have begun making inroads in Taliban territory.
articles.abstract: Though their numbers in Afghanistan remain low, Islamic State fighters have begun making inroads in Taliban territory.
articles.lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — For nearly as long as the Taliban have been at war, Maulvi Abbas has been in the middle of it, leading a small squad of insurgent fighters in Nangarhar Province and demonstrating a certain talent for survival and success.

articles.headline: Hacking Linked to China Exposes Millions of U.S. Workers
articles.snippet: The intrusion, which appears to have involved information on about four million current and former government workers, was the third such breach in the last year.
articles.abstract: The intrusion, which appears to have involved information on about four million current and former government workers, was the third such breach in the last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday announced what appeared to be one of the largest breaches of federal employees’ data, involving at least four million current and former government workers in an intrusion that officials said apparently originated in China.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: In Greek Debt Puzzle, the Game Theorists Have It
articles.snippet: In talks with European officials, Yanis Varoufakis, Greece’s finance minister, is playing the kind of game that his friend John Nash Jr., the mathematician, had in mind.
articles.abstract: In talks with European officials, Yanis Varoufakis, Greece’s finance minister, is playing the kind of game that his friend John Nash Jr., the mathematician, had in mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: That Yanis Varoufakis, the rakish Greek finance minister, would meet with senior European officials wearing a leather motorcycle jacket and open-collar shirt would probably have fascinated John F. Nash Jr., the Nobel prize -winning mathematician, game theorist and Princeton professor who was thrown from a taxi and killed last month.

articles.headline: Fed Deflects Outside Aid to Investigate Data Leaks
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s practices are the focus of investigations by the Justice Department, the House Financial Services Committee and the Fed’s inspector general.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s practices are the focus of investigations by the Justice Department, the House Financial Services Committee and the Fed’s inspector general.
articles.lead_paragraph: A review of the Federal Reserve’s response to recent leaks about its bond-buying plans raises new questions about the central bank’s efforts to police interactions with investors who can profit handsomely from inside information.

articles.headline: Unions Subdued, Scott Walker Turns to Tenure at Wisconsin Colleges
articles.snippet: Gov. Walker and leaders in Wisconsin’s Republican-held Legislature are pushing the University of Wisconsin system to give a board largely picked by the governor far more control over firings and even curriculum.
articles.abstract: Gov. Walker and leaders in Wisconsin’s Republican-held Legislature are pushing the University of Wisconsin system to give a board largely picked by the governor far more control over firings and even curriculum.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, who began building a national profile four years ago by sharply cutting collective bargaining rights for most government workers, has turned his sights to a different element of the public sector: state universities.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Tamar Lewin

articles.headline: Strong Job Growth Data Eases Concerns After Winter Dip in Economy
articles.snippet: Employers added 280,000 jobs in May, a figure that is likely to strengthen the resolve of Federal Reserve officials who are hoping to start raising interest rates later this year.
articles.abstract: Employers added 280,000 jobs in May, a figure that is likely to strengthen the resolve of Federal Reserve officials who are hoping to start raising interest rates later this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: You could almost hear the sighs of relief.

articles.headline: High Inflation Makes Ukraine’s Troubled Situation Worse
articles.snippet: While the rest of Europe tries to shrug off low inflation, Ukraine is dealing with sharply rising prices. The costs of many goods have doubled or tripled.
articles.abstract: While the rest of Europe tries to shrug off low inflation, Ukraine is dealing with sharply rising prices. The costs of many goods have doubled or tripled.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Olesia Verchenko looked over a selection of blackened avocados at a supermarket here recently.

articles.headline: U.S. Was Warned of System Open to Cyberattacks
articles.snippet: The same attackers who breached the records of millions of government workers appear to be behind similar thefts at Anthem and Premera Blue Cross, cybersecurity experts say.
articles.abstract: The same attackers who breached the records of millions of government workers appear to be behind similar thefts at Anthem and Premera Blue Cross, cybersecurity experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The inspector general at the Office of Personnel Management, which keeps the records and security clearance information for millions of current and retired federal employees, issued a report in November that essentially described the agency’s computer security system as a Chinese hacker’s dream.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: California Farmers Dig Deeper for Water, Sipping Their Neighbors Dry
articles.snippet: Those who can afford to are drilling deeper, hoping to tap new aquifers, but those new wells threaten to arouse long-dormant water disputes in the state.
articles.abstract: Those who can afford to are drilling deeper, hoping to tap new aquifers, but those new wells threaten to arouse long-dormant water disputes in the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early one morning in late April, Parvinder Hundal stood beside a hole in the ground at the edge of his almond farm near Tulare in the Central Valley of California. The hole, which was about the size of a volleyball and was encased in a shallow block of concrete, was the opening of a well, one that went hundreds of feet into the earth. He had paid $100,000 to have it drilled, but it wasn’t producing water. Mr. Hundal was hoping that if he cleaned out the well, the water would start flowing again.

articles.headline: Divided S.E.C. Reaches Compromise in Computer Sciences Case
articles.snippet: The agency extracted a $190 million penalty from the company and brought civil charges against eight former employees and executives.
articles.abstract: The agency extracted a $190 million penalty from the company and brought civil charges against eight former employees and executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has long sought to make an example out of the Computer Sciences Corporation, a large technology company with government contracts around the world. And on Friday, the S.E.C. seized the opportunity, bringing civil charges against eight former employees and executives and extracting a $190 million penalty from the company for “manipulating financial results.”
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Profits of Drug Trade Drive Economic Boom in Myanmar
articles.snippet: Companies with past ties to trafficking are building ports, dams and hotels as Myanmar strives to modernize after decades of dictatorial rule.
articles.abstract: Companies with past ties to trafficking are building ports, dams and hotels as Myanmar strives to modernize after decades of dictatorial rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Visitors flying into this buzzing tropical metropolis step into a modern glass-and-steel airport that symbolizes both Myanmar’s aspirations to rejoin the wider world after years of isolation and the country’s troubled past.
